title: Leicester City "appalled" by racism aimed at Hamza Choudhury after Mohamed Salah foul
text:

Leicester City say the club is appalled by the racist abuse directed at Hamza Choudhury after his foul on Mohamed Salah, adding that the police have been notified.

The Foxes midfielder was booked for a late challenge on the Egyptian international during Liverpool's 2-1 win over Leicester at Anfield on Saturday.

Salah attempted to play on after the challenge but was unable to run off the injury and eventually made way for Adam Lallana.

After the match Choudhury was subjected to racist abuse on social media - particularly Twitter - from football fans.

Leicester City released a statement in response to the abuse directed at the midfielder, in which they confirmed they have made contact with the police.

(Image: Getty Images)

The statement read: "We are appalled by these comments, which the club has reported to the police and to the social media platform on which they were made.

"Discriminatory behaviour has no place in football or in society and we will seek the strongest possible course of action to be taken against those responsible."

Choudhury's foul on Salah was the subject of much speculation following Liverpool's last-gap win over Leicester City.

(Image: Getty Images)

Reds boss Jurgen Klopp claimed the midfielder should have received a red card - not a booking - for the foul, while Andy Gray suggested a yellow was about right.

"Was it a tackle worthy of a sending off? In my opinion no," said Gray on beIN SPORT.

"Mo Salah endangered his well-being when he pushed him over, but there was no foul given there. You cannot say 'did he endanger the well-being of an opponent?'

(Image: PETER POWELL/EPA-EFE/REX)

"Everyone who does something to an opponent [endangers their well-being].

"That tackle is not good - it's definitely not good - and he's picked up an injury, and it's unfortunate that he's picked up an injury.

"But when that happened I bet there were a few Leicester players that said 'Well done son'.

(Image: PA)

"They were hanging on at 1-1, they had the chance of getting a fantastic result, he [Salah] was breaking away, he probably felt hard done by that they didn't get the free-kick when Salah pushed the kid over.

"And he's thought 'we didn't get the free-kick' and he's launched at him and you can just see his ankle going under his leg."
description: The Leicester City midfielder was subjected to disgraceful racist abuse on social media
